CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 18, 1949, p. 1, reads: "Accused Policemen Cleared by Trial Board - Police Trial Scene of Speculation...Top photo shows part of crowd which jammed offices of Harvey J. Scott, superintendent of police, where hearing was held Wednesday. in picture can be seen Mrs. Rachel Cox, Fifth Ward committeewoman; Mrs. Lula Hatcher, committeewoman; Mrs. Isabell Jackson, beautician; Walter Merguson, Mike Friedman, Ralph Cherner, Ben Anolik, Mrs. Olive Jackson, mother of the defendant, and other friends and well-wishers of the two officers.  Officer Hicks is seen standing at witness table where (seated) are Norman Wolken... - Harris Photo."  Portion of accompanying article reads: "Clark Watts Denies Politics Influenced Filing of Charges - Witnesses of All Races Crowd Trial Room; Wait Throughout Five-Hour Session to Defend Character of Officers Jackson and Hicks - 'Big Brass' of the city's police department, headed by Col. George E. A. Fairley, director of public safety, heard a public airing. Wednesday, of charges that two Hill District police officers were 'aiding and abetting hoodlumism' against a legitimate businessman whom they had allegedly tried to force into the rackets.  The hearing, attended my more than fifty Herron Avenue district businessmen and citizens brought together for the first time Officers Karl C. [O.] Jackson and John Hicks, and their accuser, Clark Watts.  Mrs. Watts is the owner of the Watts' Brothers Cleaner Shop, 2931 Wylie Avenue, an establishment he claimed was coveted by the officers who wished to use it for illegal and illicit purposes..."
TitMainTitle: Crowd gathered in office of Harvey J. Scott, including Charles Foggie standing on left, Rachel Cox, Lula Hatcher, Isabell Jackson, Walter Merguson, Mike Friedman, Ralph Cherner, Ben Anolik, Olive Jackson, police officer John Hicks standing on right, and Norman Wolken and Homer S. Brown seated at table
